abstracts.cdata!:
The Telephone System Expansion Project
            for the Philippines is rated as having an unsatisfactory
            outcome. The project partially achieved its physical
            objectives but achieved little of its institutional
            development and private sector development objectives. The
            loan was canceled early and there were project
            implementation delays. Also, insufficient project resources
            were applied to institutional development. The Bank's
            performance is rated as deficient on the basis of inadequate
            ownership, preparation time, project appraisal, and
            engagement with consultants. The Borrower's performance
            is rated as satisfactory. In terms of sustainability, those
            components which were implemented during the project will be
            sustainably serviced. The key lessons learned are as
            follows. A lack of ownership of a project by government and
            beneficiaries can lead to delays and difficulties. The Bank
            had decided to finance this project as a means of
            encouraging a quasi-monopoly to invest, but this approach
            cannot succeed unless that quasi-monopoly is fully committed
            to the project objectives. Convoluted on-lending
            arrangements should not be attempted unless: both government
            and borrower are highly committed; there are no simpler
            alternatives; and the Bank is prepared to accept the risk of
            delay or failure. If the borrower is unwilling to implement
            technical assistance that the Bank deems necessary, this
            should be deemed a cause to drop the project. Project
            preparation documentation and reporting systems should
            contain sufficient material for effective project monitoring
            and supervision. Finally, Bank lending to private companies
            should presume: that the company has no other alternative;
            that the company is fully committed to the project's
            objectives and investments; and that the project provides
            very substantial economic and social benefits.

5079314.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Urban development

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Telephone System
            Expansion Project are to: (a) increase telephone penetration
            and leased line facilities; (b) improve the quality of
            service; and (c) address deficiencies in sector management
            and regulation. The project will undertake the following
            activities (1) provision of new, and expansion of existing
            telephone services, mostly in provincial municipalities but
            also in metro Manila; (2) extension of its toll network to
            interconnect the remaining isolated exchanges managed by
            other operators; (3) provision of networks, throughout the
            Philippines, for leasing to business and other operators;
            (4) provision of equipment to improve its facilities; and
            (5) strengthening of its project management capabilities.
